snippet: The sparse news treatment of the pope’s first visit to the Far East is indicative of the Chinese Communist Party’s continuing attempts to maintain a tight grip on Catholicism.
abstract: Broad news coverage of Pope Francis's first visit to East Asia, which began in South Korea, is conspicuously absent in China, where Communist Party is intent on maintaining tight grip on Catholicism, even as number of Chinese followers grows each year.

byline.contributor: Choe Sang-Hun contributed reporting from Seoul, South Korea. Patrick Zuo contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: The sparse news treatment of the pope’s first visit to the Far East is indicative of the Chinese Communist Party’s continuing attempts to maintain a tight grip on Catholicism.

headline.main: For Chinese, Pope Seems Worlds Away in South Korea
headline.print_headline: For Chinese, Pope Seems Worlds Away in South Korea
